messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: SoS certification for symmetric quadratic functions and its connection to constrained Boolean hypercube optimization Adam Kurpisz was supported by SNSF project PZ00P2_174117, Aaron Potechin was supported in part by NSF grant CCF2008920.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the rank of the Sum of Squares (SoS) hierarchy over the Boolean hypercube for Symmetric Quadratic Functions (SQFs) in nùëõn variables with roots placed in points k‚àí1ùëò1k-1 and kùëòk. Functions of this type have played a central role in deepening the understanding of the performance of the SoS method for various unconstrained Boolean hypercube optimization problems, including the Max Cut problem. Recently, Lee, Prakash, de Wolf, and Yuen proved a lower bound on the SoS rank for SQFs of Œ©‚Äã(k‚Äã(n‚àík))Œ©ùëòùëõùëò\Omega(\sqrt{k(n-k)}) and conjectured the lower bound of Œ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõ\Omega(n) by similarity to a polynomial representation of the nùëõn-bit OR function. Using Chebyshev polynomials, we refute the Lee‚ÄîPrakash‚Äîde Wolf‚ÄîYuen conjecture and prove that the SoS rank for SQFs is at most O‚Äã(n‚Äãk‚Äãlog‚Å°(n))ùëÇùëõùëòùëõO(\sqrt{nk}\log(n)). We connect this result to two constrained Boolean hypercube optimization problems. First, we provide a degree O‚Äã(n)ùëÇùëõO(\sqrt{n}) SoS certificate that matches the known SoS rank lower bound for an instance of Min Knapsack, a problem that was intensively studied in the literature. Second, we study an instance of the Set Cover problem for which Bienstock and Zuckerberg conjectured an SoS rank lower bound of n/4ùëõ4n/4. We refute the Bienstock‚ÄîZuckerberg conjecture and provide a degree O‚Äã(n‚Äãlog‚Å°(n))ùëÇùëõùëõO(\sqrt{n}\log(n)) SoS certificate for this problem.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Expander flows, geometric embeddings and graph partitioning",
        "A nearly tight sum-of-squares lower bound for the planted clique problem",
        "Dictionary learning and tensor decomposition via the sum-of-squares method",
        "Noisy tensor completion via the sum-of-squares hierarchy",
        "Rounding semidefinite programming hierarchies via global correlation",
        "Proofs, beliefs, and algorithms through the lens of sum-of-squares",
        "Polynomial integrality gaps for strong sdp relaxations of densest k-subgraph",
        "Subset algebra lift operators for 0-1 integer programming (extended version)",
        "Semidefinite optimization and convex algebraic geometry",
        "Computation of the Lasserre ranks of some polytopes",
        "On the matrix-cut rank of polyhedra",
        "Sparse sum-of-squares certificates on finite abelian groups",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for sherrington-kirkpatrick via planted affine planes",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming",
        "Complexity of positivstellensatz proofs for the knapsack",
        "Linear lower bound on degrees of positivstellensatz calculus proofs for the parity",
        "Complexity of semi-algebraic proofs",
        "Complexity of null-and positivstellensatz proofs",
        "Lasserre hierarchy, higher eigenvalues, and approximation schemes for graph partitioning and quadratic integer programming with psd objectives",
        "Fast spectral algorithms from sum-of-squares proofs: tensor decomposition and planted sparse vectors",
        "Robust moment estimation and improved clustering via sum of squares",
        "Sum of squares lower bounds for refuting any CSP",
        "A tight degree 4 sum-of-squares lower bound for the sherrington-kirkpatrick hamiltonian",
        "Sum-of-squares bounds via boolean function analysis",
        "Sum-of-squares hierarchy lower bounds for symmetric formulations",
        "Tight sum-of-squares lower bounds for binary polynomial optimization problems",
        "On the hardest problem formulations for the 0/1 lasserre hierarchy",
        "An unbounded sum-of-squares hierarchy integrality gap for a polynomially solvable problem",
        "An explicit exact SDP relaxation for nonlinear 0-1 programs",
        "A comparison of the Sherali-Adams, Lov√°sz-Schrijver, and Lasserre relaxations for 0-1 programming",
        "Lower bound for the number of iterations in semidefinite hierarchies for the cut polytope",
        "Lower bounds on the size of semidefinite programming relaxations",
        "On the sum-of-squares degree of symmetric quadratic functions",
        "On the shannon capacity of a graph",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for planted clique",
        "An nùëõn job, one machine sequencing algorithm for minimizing the number of late jobs",
        "Some np-complete problems in quadratic and nonlinear programming",
        "Global quadratic optimization via conic relaxation",
        "Structured Semidefinite Programs and Semialgebraic Geometry Methods in Robustness and Optimization",
        "On the degree of polynomials that approximate symmetric boolean functions (preliminary version)",
        "Sum of squares bounds for the ordering principle",
        "Exact tensor completion with sum-of-squares",
        "The chebyshev polynomials",
        "Exact semidefinite programming relaxations with truncated moment matrix for binary polynomial optimization problems",
        "Fast and robust tensor decomposition with applications to dictionary learning",
        "Class of global minimum bounds of polynomial functions",
        "Improved convergence analysis of lasserre‚Äôs measure-based upper bounds for polynomial minimization on compact sets",
        "The power of sherali-adams relaxations for general-valued csps",
        "Csp gaps and reductions in the lasserre hierarchy",
        "A note on quantum algorithms and the minimal degree of œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon-error polynomials for symmetric functions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in SoS certification for symmetric quadratic functions and its connection to constrained Boolean hypercube optimization Adam Kurpisz was supported by SNSF project PZ00P2_174117, Aaron Potechin was supported in part by NSF grant CCF2008920., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
